lessons.title: Sounds of Spanish
lessons.text:
As you’re beginning to learn a language, one of the most important things you can do early on is learn the foundation of how that language sounds. This will give you consistency in your pronunciation, and most importantly, let you read things and know how to actually say them! 

 Let’s take a look into the sounds of Spanish, and how they differ from English.

---

First off, **vowels!** In Spanish, vowels don’t change their sounds nearly as much as in English. They stay pretty consistent.  

**A** - Always pronounced like “ah” 
**E**- Always pronounced like the “e” in “best” 
**I** - Always pronounced like “ee” 
**O** - Always pronounced like “oh” 
**U** - Always pronounced like the vowels at the end of “blue”   

---

All right, let’s talk **consonants**. For the most part, the consonants are quite similar to their English counterparts. There are a few differences that we’ll highlight here.  

**C** - Similar to English, “c” often simply sounds like the letter “k.” However, if it comes before an “i” or “e,” it sounds like an “s” (ex. “carcel” is pronounced like “car-sell”)

**D** - Think of the Spanish “d” as halfway between a “d” and “th.” It has a kind of soft combined “dth” sound, which we don’t have in English. Listen carefully as you encounter this sound in Spanish, it can be a little tricky.

---

**G** - If a “g” comes before “i” or “e,” it makes more of a soft “h” sound (ex. “gente” or “gimnasio”). Everywhere else, a “g” is hard, like the English “goal.”

**H** - This is one of the first sounds you’ll encounter in Spanish, by saying “hola” (hello). The “h” sound in Spanish is *almost* silent. You don’t really pronounce it, but it does give a little bit of breathy air to the following vowel sound.

**J** - The Spanish “j” is always followed by a vowel, and sounds like an English “h” (for example, **jugo** sounds like “hoo-go”).

---

**Q** - “Q” is always followed by a “u” and the combination sounds like the English “k” (ex. “quiero” sounds like “key-air-o”).

**R** - “R” is a little hard to describe, as it’s essentially a softer version of the English “r.” Basically, if you drop the hard “er” sound at the end of the letter and replace it with just a breath, you get the Spanish “r.” This one’s difficult as well, so be sure to listen and practice!

**V** - “V” is somewhat of a combination between the English “v” and “b.”

---

**X** - For the most part, “x” sounds like the English letters “ks,” like in stic**ks**. However, in some proper nouns, the x sounds more like an English “h” (like in “México,” most notably, which is pronounced like “Meh-hee-ko”).

**Y** - Normally sounds like the English “y,” such as in the word “yogurt.” However, if it stands alone like the Spanish word for “and” (“y”), it sounds like “ee.”
 
**Z** - “Z” in Spanish sounds much more like an English “s.” It’s slightly different in that there’s a *little bit* of the harder English “z” sounds that sneaks in there, but you’ll notice that as you listen to more native speakers.

---

Whew! That’s a lot of stuff we just covered. Don’t worry about memorizing everything here, this is more for reference so you can come back to it as you move on. Speaking of which, let’s get on to actually learning some useful vocab!

lessons.title: You already know Spanish
lessons.text:
For a lot of historical reasons that are really interesting but not super relevant right now, Spanish shares a ton of common vocabulary with English. Many of the words you know and use everyday in English can be translated into Spanish with just small changes. These words fall into different categories; let’s talk about the first in this lesson.

---

**-or Words** 
You get this one for free. Many words that end in “or” in English can be translated into Spanish with either no change or just a minor change in spelling. Woo! How’s that for some starter vocab?

*(Note that “el” means “the” and “un” means “a” or “an.” So “el doctor” is “the doctor,” and “un doctor” is “a doctor.”)*

---

Here’s a short list of some common “-or” words you might want to use: 

- **el doctor**
- **el color**
- **el error**
- **un tractor**
- **un interior**
- **un profesor**
- **exterior**
- **superior**
- **favor**

---

*Keep in mind with “profesor” that the “ss” turns into just a single “s.”*

*Also, you can use either “el” or “un” with any of the words in this list, we just used a little of each to show you how it can be done.* 

---

Though the spelling of these words doesn’t change between English and Spanish, the pronunciation does. All the pronunciation rules from the previous lesson still apply, of course. 

In addition, on these “or” words in Spanish, the emphasis is on the last syllable. So “color” is emphasized like “co-LOR.” *(Keep in mind that the letter “o” always sounds like “oh” in Spanish)*  

---

Not bad for your second lesson in Spanish, right? We already know a bunch of words that we don’t even have to memorize. And the above list is just a small sampling. Here are some for the road:  

Are you making a movie and need a **director** and **editor**? How about an **inspector**, a **tutor**, or a **mentor**? Of course, we can’t forget **vector**, **sector**, or **factor**. All of these are the same in both Spanish and English. And the list goes on!

lessons.title: “-al” the words
lessons.text:
The next category we’ll cover is words that end in “al.” Similar to “-or” words, these are often the same in both English and Spanish. 

---

Let’s take a look at some examples:

**animal**
**criminal**
**canal**
**central**
**comercial**
**legal**
**local**
**musical**
**natural**
**personal**
**rural**
**social**

---

Again, like the “-or” words, these “-al” words have the emphasis on the last syllable (ex. “ani-MAL”).

lessons.title: It’s not impossi-ble
lessons.text:
Like the previous categories, words that end in “-ble” are often the same in both languages. One quick spelling note here: Spanish never uses a double “s” like we do in English. So, when translating these words from English to Spanish, any “ss” becomes a single “s.” For example, “possible” in English becomes **“posible”** in Spanish.  

---

This is true across the board, so keep an eye out for those small differences! Let’s take a look at some words ending in “-ble.”  

- **posible**
- **imposible**
- **notable**
- **flexible**
- **visible**
- **formidable**
- **probable**
- **honorable**
- **noble**
- **horrible**
- **inevitable**

---

*On these words, the emphasis is placed on the second to last syllable. So “imposible” is “im-po-**SI**-ble.”*

lessons.title: “-ic” what you mean
lessons.text:
This next category is made up of words that, in English, end with “-ic.” To magically transform them into the proper Spanish words, simply add an “o” to the end of the English word. 

Well, not quite so magical, I’m afraid. Most of these words end up with an accent somewhere in the middle. Still, it's nice that they're at least easily recognizable and understandable without learning anything new!

---

Let’s take a look at our list of words here and then go over what that accent means.

- **Atlántico**
- **público**
- **romántico**
- **democrático**
- **artístico**
- **aristocrático**
- **elástico**
- **eléctrico**
- **automático**
- **fantástico**
- **clásico**

---

The accent that appears in all these words doesn’t change the pronunciation of either the word or the letter it appears over. Instead, it simply marks where the *emphasis* is placed. In the past few categories, the emphasis was always in the same place, so we didn’t need it, but here it switches around a bit. 

For example, the emphasis on **“público”** is “**PU**-bli-co,” whereas **“fantástico”** (which has the accent on a different syllable) is “fan-**TA**-sti-co.”

lessons.title: Excellent elephants
lessons.text:
This category is made up of words that end in “-ent” or “-ant” in English. For many of these words, all you have to do is add the letter “e” to the end, and *voila* (wrong language, I know): you have the correct word in Spanish. 

---

*Keep in mind that the other rules of Spanish spelling still apply. For example, when translating “different” into Spanish, the double “f” in the middle becomes a single “f” (“diferente”). Similarly, “elephant” switches out the “ph” for an “f” and becomes “elefante.”*

---

- **presidente**
- **accidente**
- **cliente**
- **elefante**
- **inteligente**
- **excelente**
- **importante**
- **diferente**
- **conveniente**

---

Like the “-ble” words a few lessons ago, these “-ent” and “-ant” words have the emphasis on the second-to-last syllable. So “importante” is “im-por-**TAN**-te.”

lessons.title: Double or nothing
lessons.text:
You might have noticed through the previous lessons that there are some slight spelling differences between Spanish and English, even when the words are otherwise almost identical. Fortunately, those spelling differences are pretty straightforward. Let’s take a look!

---

**“Ph” becomes “f”**

- alphabet -> **alfabeto**
- elephant -> **elefante**
- telephone -> **teléfono**
- photo -> **foto**
- phrase -> **frase**

---

**“Th” becomes “t”**

- author -> **autor**
- Catholic -> **Católico**
- throne -> **trono**
- authentic -> **auténtico**

---

**Only double “l” and “r”**

The only letters that are ever doubled in Spanish are “l” and “r.” A double “l” makes a “y” sound (*pollo* sounds like “poyo”). A double “rr” is rolled, which is possibly the most difficult sound in the Spanish language for those coming from an English-speaking background. As with everything, it just takes practice!

---

In the case where an English word has two of the same letter next to each other, that doubled letter just becomes a single one in Spanish.

- annual -> **anual**
- attractive -> **atractivo**
- different -> **diferente**
- apparent -> **aparente**

---

**What about double “c”?**

Okay, you got me. Sometimes you’ll see words with a “cc” in them. For example, “action” becomes “acción” in Spanish. However, despite being right next to each other, the two “c’s” have different sounds and occur in different syllables. The first “c” sounds like a “k,” and the second has an “s” sound. So “acción” sounds like “ahk-see-on.”

---

Remember also that there’s a syllable break between the two “c’s,” like so:

- *correc-ción*
- *direc-ción*
- *instruc-ción*

---

Why is this “cc” so weird? Well, it’s a little tricky. What’s actually happening in these cases is that a “tion” in an English word changes to be “ción,” which brings us to our next point!

---

**“tion” becomes “ción”**

As we just noted, English words switch out their “tion” for a “ción” when switching to Spanish. Keep in mind that if the word *ends* with “tion,” it changes to “ción,” with an accent over the “o.” If the “tion” is in the middle of the word, it changes to “cion” with *no* accent over the “o.”

---

Take a look at the examples below.

- convention -> **convención**
- conventional -> **convencional**
- section -> **sección**
- nation -> **nación**
- national -> **nacional**

*Notice that neither convencional nor nacional have the accented "ó."*

lessons.title: You and me
lessons.text:
Before we go any further, it’s important to learn about pronouns in Spanish so that you can talk about yourself and others. 

---

Here’s the rundown:

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **yo**  | I/me |
| **tú**  | you |
| **usted**  | you (formal) |
| **él**  | he |
| **ella**  | she |
| **nosotros/nosotras**  | us |
| **ellos/ellas**  | them |
| **ustedes**  | you (all) |

---

You'll notice that there are two ways to say "you." **Usted** is the formal way, and it’s good to know, but it’s not used as commonly as **tú** in real life, so we won’t focus on it. Go ahead and stick with **tú**.

---

*Also note that **nosotras** and **ellas** are feminine, and used only when the **entire group** being referred to is female. We'll talk about this in more detail later.*

lessons.title: To be
lessons.text:
One of the most useful things you can learn early on is how to use state-of-being, saying things like “I am” and all of its various forms: he/she/it is, we/they are.

---

The verb for “to be” in Spanish is **ser**. This is called the infinitive form, and in English we make the infinitive form just by putting “to” before a verb (e.g. to be, to run, to eat). 

Just like in English, we only use this form when we want to say something like “I want **to be** a doctor” or “I need **to eat**.” 

We’ll circle back to the infinitive form in a bit, but for now, you can just keep it in the back of your mind, as we won’t be using it right now.

---

Verbs in Spanish have **conjugations**, which just means that they take different predictable forms based on who’s doing the action and if they’re doing it in the past, present, or future.

---

We’ll dive into more verbs later, but for now, all you need to know is that “ser” is an **irregular verb**, so it doesn’t really follow the rules that most other verbs do. Because of that, you’ll just have to memorize the different forms it takes.

---

Here's the conjugation chart for the verb **ser** (*to be*):

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **ser**  | to be |
| **(yo) soy** | I am |
| **(tú) eres** | you are |
| **(él/ella) es** | he/she is | 
| **(nosotros) somos** | we are |
| **(ellos) son** | they are |
| **(ustedes) son** | you (all) are |

---

And here are some example sentences:

**Yo soy un doctor.**
*I am a doctor.*

**Tú eres un actor.**
*You are an actor.*

**Él es un estudiante.**
He is a student.

**Ella es un autor.**
*She is an author.*

**Es un rumor.**
*(It) is a rumor.*
*(Note that if you want to say “it is ...” you leave off the “it” and simply say “is ...”)*

---

**Ellos son directores.**
*They are directors.*

**Ellas son clientes.**
*They are clients.*

**Ustedes son criminales.**
*You all are criminals.*

**Nosotros somos agentes.**
We are agents.

**Nosotras somos pacientes.**
We are patients.

lessons.title: Masculine or feminine?
lessons.text:
For the most part, Spanish should feel pretty familiar to you if you're coming from an English-speaking background. 

However, there are a few big differences between Spanish and English, and this lesson will be your first encounter with one of the most noticeable differences: **grammatical gender**.

---

In Spanish, every noun has a gender, meaning that it's either "masculine" or "feminine." 

I know, it sounds weird. It kind of is, actually: it means that you have to change how you use articles (a, an, the) and adjectives depending on the gender of the noun.

---

If a noun is referring to a person or animal, it's pretty straightforward to tell which gender a noun is or should be, as it simply *matches the gender of the creature you're talking about*. 

---

Let's look at a few examples:

| **Masculine** | **Feminine**  |
| ----------- | ----------- |
| **el hombre**     | **la mujer**     |
| *the man*  | *the woman*  |
| **un niño**     | **una niña**     |
| *a boy*  | *a girl*  |
| **el gato**     | **la gata**     | 
| *the (male) cat*  | *the (female) cat*  |
| **un perro**    | **una perra**    |
| *a (male) dog*  | *a (female) dog*  |

*Note: the actual translation of the animals above into English would just be "dog" or "cat" and the gender would just be understood, but not explicitly translated, hence the parentheses*

---

As illustrated in the table, in Spanish you use the articles **el** *(the)* and **un** *(a/an)* with masculine nouns, and you use **la** *(the)* and **una** *(a/an)* with feminine nouns.

One tricky part: if the noun is plural (e.g. "dogs") the article for "the" changes. Instead of "el" and "la," you use **los** and **las** with masculine and feminine nouns, respectively.

---

Here's a look at the same table using plurals.

| **Masculine** | **Feminine**  |
| ----------- | ----------- |
| **los hombres**     | **las mujeres**     |
| *the men*  | *the women*  |
| **los niños**     | **las niñas**     |
| *the boys*  | *the girls*  |
| **los gatos**     | **las gatas**     | 
| *the male cats*  | *the female cats*  |
| **los perros**    | **las perras**    |
| *the male dogs*  | *the female dogs*  |

---

The same rules for plurals apply here as when you're using pronouns like nosotros/nosotras and ellos/ellas—*use the feminine version of the noun only if the entire group consists of females*. 

For example, if there is a group entirely of young girls, you might say "las niñas," but if it's a mix of both boys and girls, then you would use "los niños." 

*In this case, "los niños" would translate as "the children" instead of "the boys."*

---

I know this seems complicated at first (because it is), but it becomes pretty straightforward with some practice.

lessons.title: Everything else
lessons.text:
So grammatical gender makes sense for living things, right? The gender of the word simply corresponds to the gender of the person or animal you're referencing.

---

But as we mentioned before, *all* nouns in Spanish have a grammatical gender, and it's not quite so simple when that noun refers to something inanimate. We can't really ask, "What gender is this toaster?" to figure it out!

---

For all these other nouns, the grammatical gender is *constant*. It's just a part of the word, and it really doesn't have anything to do with whether that word is referring to something "masculine" or "feminine." 

*It's purely a grammatical concept.*

---

For example, I might think the word for **"sword"** would be masculine, if I were guessing based on association. 

But it's actually feminine: **"la espada."** 

Conversely, I would guess that the word for **"dress"** would be feminine, since a dress is traditionally considered a woman's garment. 

Nope! It's masculine: **"el vestido."**

---

You'll notice a common theme going forward, that *most* words that end in "-o" are masculine, and *most* words that end in "-a" are feminine. 

This certainly isn't always the case, so the most reliable way to tell if a noun is masculine or feminine is to look at which **definite article** it uses: *"el"* or *"la."*

lessons.title: More like guidelines
lessons.text:
In the last lesson, we said that nouns that end in "-o" are generally masculine, and nouns that end in "-a" are generally feminine.

This is a pretty good guide, but it's far from a rule. Not to mention that there are nouns that don't end in "-o" or "-a," which really throws a wrench in the whole concept.

Let's talk about some of these other cases.

---

**Opposites**

There are a handful of nouns that not only ignore the guidelines of "-o" or "-a" endings, they reverse it entirely by having a masculine noun with an "-a" ending and a feminine noun with an "-o" ending.

There aren't many of them (fortunately), but they can be tricky unless you know their definite articles.

---

Here are a few of the most common ones you'll encounter.

| *Spanish* | *English* |
| ---------- | ---------|
| el día | the day |
| el mapa | the map |
| el planeta | the planet |
| la mano | the hand |
| la radio | the radio |
| la foto | the photo |
| la moto | the motorbike |

---

**More people-related words**

Some nouns that refer to people have both a masculine and feminine form, depending on who they're referencing:

| *Masculine* | *Feminine* | *English* |
| ---------- | -------- | ---------|
| el doctor | la doctora | the doctor |
| el profesor | la profesora | the professor |
| el maestro | la maestra | the teacher |
| el arquitecto | la arquitecta | the architect |
| el cocinero | la cocinera | the chef |

---

It would be nice if this were the case across the board, but it isn't. Some nouns that refer to people use the same form whether they're referring to a man or a woman.

However, the definite article does change to let us know whether the noun is masculine or feminine.

---

| *Masculine* | *Feminine* | *English* |
| ---------- | -------- | ---------|
| el estudiante | la estudiante | the student |
| el artista | la artista | the artist |
| el atleta | la atleta | the athlete |
| el dentista | la dentista | the dentist |
| el modelo | la modelo | the model |
| el soldado | la soldado | the soldier |
*(pay attention to the definite articles here)*

---

**"-ma" words**

Even though they end in an "-a," words that end in "-ma" specifically are almost always masculine.

| *Spanish* | *English* |
| ---------- | ---------|
| el idioma | the language |
| el programa | the program |
| el problema | the problem |
| el drama | the drama |
| el poema | the poem |
| el sistema | the system |

---

This pattern is actually more of a rule. Almost all "-ma" words you encounter will be masculine, with only a couple notable exceptions:

| *Spanish* | *English* |
| ---------- | ---------|
| la pluma | the pen |
| la cama | the bed |
| la forma | the form |

---

**-sión, -ción, -dad, -tad, -tud**

All words that end in **-sión**, **-ción**, **-dad**, **-tad**, or **-tud** are feminine.

---

| *Spanish* | *English* |
| ---------- | ---------|
| la televisión | the television |
| la decisión | the decision |
| la acción | the action |
| la conversación | the conversation |
| la ciudad | the city |
| la universidad | the university |
| la libertad | the liberty |
| la virtud | the virtue |
| la gratitud | the gratitude |

lessons.title: Plurals and then some
lessons.text:
We already know that the definite article "el" corresponds with masculine nouns, and the article "la" corresponds with feminine nouns. 

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **el perro**  | the dog |
| **la casa** | the house |

---

These change, however, when the noun is plural. Instead of "el," we use "los," and instead of "la" we use "las."

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **los perros**  | the dogs |
| **las casas** | the houses |

---

So, if those are *definite* articles, then what are *indefinite articles*? In English, the definite article is "the," and the indefinite articles are "a" or "an." 

When we say "*the* dog," we're referring to a specific dog. When we say "*a* dog," we're just referring to some (indefinite) dog in general.

---

The same is true of Spanish, as we've seen in previous lessons and drills:

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **un perro**  | a dog |
| **una casa** | a house |

*"Un" is used with masculine nouns and "una" with feminine nouns.*

---

Since we're already on the subject of indefinite articles, now is a perfect time to go over how to say "some" of something in Spanish.

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **unos perros**  | some dogs |
| **unas casas** | some houses |

Pretty simple, right? Just use "unos" with masculine nouns, and "unas" with feminine ones.

lessons.title: Allow me to introduce myself
lessons.text:
¡Hola! ¿Cómo estás? In this lesson, we're going to go through an example exchange of two people meeting for the first time, and later on we'll learn how to talk about ourselves more in-depth.

---

Here are a few good phrases that make up a basic personal introduction. Don't worry about memorizing them right now, we'll practice later on. This is just to get familiar.

**¡Hola! ¿Cómo estás?**
*Hello! How are you?*

**Bien, ¿y tú?**
*I'm well, and you?*

---

**Muy bien. ¿Cómo te llamas?**
*I'm very well. What's your name?*

**Me llamo Juan.**
*My name's Juan.*

**Mucho gusto. Yo soy Rosa.**
*Nice to meet you. I'm Rosa.*

---

You'll notice that there are two different ways to state your name: **Me llamo ___** and **Yo soy ___**. We'll talk more about the distinction a little later, but for now just remember that they can be used interchangeably and both have the same function: to introduce yourself and tell someone your name.

---

In English, when someone asks "How are you?" we tend to answer "I'm good" more often than "I'm well." Spanish simplifies this, since the word **bien** can be translated as either **well** or **good**.

---

So, when translating from Spanish into English, feel free to go with whichever sounds more natural.

---

There are a bunch of other things we could talk about here, but we'll save them for further down the road. Let's put our newfound knowledge of Spanish greetings to use!

lessons.title: Hello, goodbye
lessons.text:
Let's go over a few of the key greetings you'll need right away, just to say hello and goodbye.

There are, of course, lots of others, including slang and regional words, we'll encounter those as we go. For now, let's focus on the basics.

---

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **hola**  | hello |
| **adiós**  | goodbye |
| **hasta pronto**  | see you soon *(lit: until soon)* |
| **hasta luego**  | see you later *(lit: until later)* |
| **nos vemos**  | see you later *(lit: we'll see each other)* |
| **buenos días**  | good morning |
| **buenas tardes**  | good afternoon |
| **buenas noches**  | good evening, good night |

---

Note that **hasta luego** and **nos vemos** are fairly interchangeable. Both serve the purpose of saying "I'll see you later," they're just two different ways of communicating the same thing.

**Hasta luego** literally means "until later," while **nos vemos** means "we'll see each other."

lessons.title: Location, location, location
lessons.text:
One thing you'll probably want to be able to talk about early on as you meet new people is where you're from. Let's take a look at a quick example of a conversation covering this topic.

---

**¿De dónde eres?**
*Where are you from?*

**Soy de México. ¿Y tú?**
*I'm from Mexico. And you?*

**Soy de los Estados Unidos. Vivo en Nueva York.**
*I'm from the United States. I live in New York.*

---

Not too complicated, right? Don't worry about understanding every single word, exactly how all the verbs are working, or any of that right now.

We're simply trying to get familiar with some of these simple greetings, and you'll continue to see these as we go forward.

---

Here's some of the vocab that appears in this exchange:

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **dónde**  | where |
| **de**  | from |
| **soy**  | I am |
| **eres**  | you are |

---

Let's take one more look at this dialogue, this time just in Spanish.

**¿De dónde eres?**

**Soy de México. ¿Y tú?**

**Soy de los Estados Unidos. Vivo en Nueva York.**

---

Keep in mind that we'll introduce more place names (countries, states, cities, etc.) in upcoming lessons. Right now, it's mostly important to focus on the structure of the conversation.

lessons.title: Another day, another peso
lessons.text:
One of the first things we do when meeting someone new is ask them what they do for work. In English, we have a few different ways we might say this:

- What do you do?
- What do you do for work?
- Where do you work?

---

Of course, there are others as well, but these are some of the most common. Similarly, Spanish has a whole bunch of different ways to ask after someone's occupation, but we'll focus on a few *main* ones in this lesson.

---

**¿En qué trabajas?**
*What do you do for work?*
*Literally: In what do you work?*

**¿Cuál es su profesión?**
*What is your profession?*

**¿En dónde trabajas?**
*Where do you work?*

---

**¿En qué trabajas?** (*What do you do for work?*) can be used for any situation. It's a little less formal, and is a pretty good go-to for asking what someone does, no matter who they are.

---

**¿Cuál es su profesión?** (*What is your profession?*) is more formal, and it might sound a little awkward to say to someone of your own age bracket or younger. Still, it's a good one to know for situations where you're talking to someone to whom you'd like to show a little extra respect.

---

**¿En dónde trabajas?** (*Where do you work?*) is asking after the specific location where someone works or company that they work for. They likely won't respond with their profession here, but will instead say something like "I work at a hospital" (*Trabajo en un hospital*) or "I work at Google" (*Trabajo en Google*).

lessons.title: Lights, camera, action!
lessons.text:
Recently, we talked about grammatical gender (which we'll circle back to later) and how it's one of the two big differences between Spanish and English. Let's talk about the second major difference: **verb conjugation**.

---

*Conjugated verbs are verbs which have been changed to communicate one or more of the following: person, number, gender, tense, aspect, mood, or voice. - Your Dictionary*

---

Now, we do have verb conjugation in English, we just don't have the variety or specificity that Spanish has, which is where the difficulty lies. In English, our verbs mostly change form when they change tense. 

For example: *cooked, cook, will cook.* This is relatively easy, especially with the more complex forms, where we just add another word in front: *had cooked, have cooked, is/are/am cooking, etc.*

---

If you think back to the lesson where we talked about the verb **ser** *(to be)*, you'll remember that we already encountered how verbs work in Spanish: they change form to indicate not only the tense and state of an action, but also *who is performing the action.* 

---

Let's take a look at the present tense of "to walk" to see the difference:

| **English** | **Spanish** | 
| ----------- | ------------ |
| I walk     |  (Yo) camino    |
| you walk     |  (tú) caminas   |
| he/she walks     |  (él/ella) camina   |
| we walk     |  (nosotros) caminamos   |
| they walk     |  (ellos) caminan    |
| you (all) walk     |  (ustedes) caminan   |

---

In this case, the English only changes with the third person singular (he/she/it walks), while the Spanish changes for every case except for ellos/ellas and ustedes. 

Imagine *this many* forms for every verb tense, and you'll see why many Spanish learners find verb conjugations to be quite the headache.

---

Fortunately, Spanish words tend to follow grammar rules more closely than their English counterparts, so rather than memorizing dozens of different versions of each verb, we'll focus on understanding the basic rules that govern their transformations. 

This will allow you to use these patterns to conjugate verbs like a pro!

---

The verbs that follow the rules are called **regular verbs**, and those that don't are **irregular** (**ser** is one of them, as we've seen). 

We'll go over irregular verbs as they show up, so don't worry about those for now. In the next lessons and drills, we'll learn how to conjugate regular verbs into their present tense forms. 

---

Unlike English, which is all over the place, all Spanish verbs have one of three endings: 
**"-ar"** verbs (like **hablar** - *to speak, to talk*)
**"-er"** verbs (like **comer** - *to eat*)
**"-ir"** verbs (like **vivir** - *to live*)

Let's go over these one at a time, and put some action into our sentences!

lessons.title: -ar you ready for this?
lessons.text:
The first group of verbs we'll go over are "-ar" verbs. Not surprisingly, these words all end in "-ar" and conjugate the same way (unless you encounter an irregular verb).

---

Let's take a look at an example before talking about the details: 

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **hablar**  | to speak |
| **(yo) hablo** | I speak |
| **(tú) hablas** | you speak |
| **(él/ella) habla** | he/she speaks | 
| **(nosotros) hablamos** | we speak |
| **(ellos) hablan** | they speak |
| **(ustedes) hablan** | you (all) speak |

---

Perhaps you're already starting to see the pattern. Essentially, we take the infinitive form of the verb (the one with "-ar" on the end), we take off the last two letters, and then add the proper ending depending on who we're talking about. Not too crazy, right?

---

*Grammar note:* 
Remember that the form of the verb when it ends in "-ar" is the **infinitive**, and it's the same as when we have a "to" in front of a verb in English (e.g. **caminar** = to walk).

The dictionary tells us that the infinitive is "the basic form of a verb, without an inflection binding it to a particular subject or tense." So, it doesn't have any inherent action, it just kind of is.

---

So, for "-ar" verbs, we remove the "-ar." We'll use the word **estudiar** (*to study*) as an example. To start conjugating, **estudiar** becomes **estudi**. Then, we just add the ending that corresponds to the person who's performing the action. 

Take a look at the next chart to see the endings by themselves.

---

|  **Pronoun**  |  **Ending**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **yo**  | -o |
| **tú** | -as |
| **él/ella** | -a | 
| **nosotros/nosotras** | -amos |
| **ellos/ellas** | -an |
| **ustedes** | -an |

---

So if we wanted to say "we study," it should be **estudiamos** (**estudiar - "ar" + "amos" = estudiamos**). And if we need to say "I study" it should be **estudio** (**estudiar - "ar" + "o" = estudio**). So now we can say **Estudio español!** (*I study Spanish!*).

---

It can be a bit overwhelming at first to keep all the verb forms straight, but with a little practice, and by focusing on the rules instead of memorizing the many words themselves, you'll get the hang of it before long!

---

For reference, here is the complete present tense conjugation chart for **estudiar**.

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **estudiar**  | to study |
| **(yo) estudio** | I study |
| **(tú) estudias** | you study |
| **(él/ella) estudia** | he/she studies | 
| **(nosotros) estudiamos** | we study |
| **(ellos) estudian** | they study |
| **(ustedes) estudian** | you (all) study |

---

And here are a few common "-ar" verbs that you can use right away.

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **hablar**  | to speak |
| **estudiar**  | to study |
| **usar**  | to use |
| **practicar**  | to practice |
| **caminar**  | to walk |
| **cocinar**  | to cook |
| **escuchar**  | to listen |
| **comprar**  | to buy |

lessons.title: -er, where were we?
lessons.text:
Okay, let's talk about "-er" verbs. The process for conjugating them is exactly the same as the "-ar" verbs we just practiced, only with a different pattern of endings. 

First, we remove the "-er" from the end, then attach the proper ending for the subject we're talking about.

---

*Quick note here: many useful "-er" verbs are irregular for some reason, so we'll cover those a little bit later. Right now we'll focus on the regular verbs that follow the rules.*

---

Just like last time, let's look at an example using the word **comer** (*to eat*). See if you can spot the pattern.

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **comer**  | to eat |
| **(yo) como** | I eat |
| **(tú) comes** | you eat |
| **(él/ella) come** | he/she eats | 
| **(nosotros) comemos** | we eat |
| **(ellos) comen** | they eat |
| **(ustedes) comen** | you (all) eat |

---

Are you starting to get the hang of it? Now let's take a look at the endings by themselves.

|  **Pronoun**  |  **Ending**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **yo**  | -o |
| **tú** | -es |
| **él/ella** | -e | 
| **nosotros/nosotras** | -emos |
| **ellos/ellas** | -en |
| **ustedes** | -en |

*If you'll notice, this pattern is almost exactly the same as the "-ar" verbs, except that we use e's instead of a's.*

---

Let's look at the "-er" endings and "-ar" endings side-by-side to see the difference:

|  **Pronoun**  |  **"-ar" Verb Endings**  |  **"-er" Verb Endings**  | 
| --------- | -------- | -------- |
| **yo**  | -o | -o |
| **tú** | -as | -es |
| **él** | -a | -e | 
| **nosotros** | -amos | -emos |
| **ellos** | -an | -en |
| **ustedes** | -an | -en |

---

So, for the present tense conjugations, just remember that "-ar" verbs use a's, and "-er" verbs use e's. That's less memorizing you have to do, and we're all about efficiency!

---

Again, let's look at the full conjugations for an "-ar" word and an "-er" word side-by-side. This time we'll use **cocinar** (*to cook*) and **beber** (*to drink*).

|  **Pronoun**  |  **To cook**  |  **To drink**  | 
| --------- | -------- | -------- |
| **yo**  | cocino | bebo |
| **tú** | cocinas | bebes |
| **él/ella** | cocina | bebe | 
| **nosotros** | cocinamos | bebemos |
| **ellos** | cocinan | beben |
| **ustedes** | cocinan | beben |

---

And here are a few key words we'll be practicing in the next few lessons.

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **comer**  | to eat |
| **beber**  | to drink |
| **leer**  | to read |
| **correr**  | to run |
| **responder**  | to respond/to answer |
| **vender**  | to sell |
| **aprender**  | to learn |

lessons.title: -ir and there
lessons.text:
Okay, the last category of verbs is those that end in "-ir". Let's look at the conjugation for the word **escribir** (*to write*).

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **escribir**  | to write |
| **(yo) escribo** | I write |
| **(tú) escribes** | you write |
| **(él/ella) escribe** | he/she writes | 
| **(nosotros) escribimos** | we write |
| **(ellos) escriben** | they write |
| **(ustedes) escriben** | you (all) write |

---

The key point to note here is that the conjugation for "-ir" verbs (in the present tense only) is exactly the same as "-er" verbs, *except for the first person plural (nosotros/nosotras)*.

---

Take a look at an "-er" verb and "-ir" verb side-by-side: 

|  **Pronoun**  |  **To drink**  |  **To live**  | 
| --------- | -------- | -------- |
| **yo**  | bebo | vivo |
| **tú** | bebes | vives |
| **él/ella** | bebe | vive | 
| **nosotros/nosotras** | **bebemos** | **vivimos** |
| **ellos/ellas** | beben | viven |
| **ustedes** | beben | viven |

---

That makes the present tense pretty easy to remember. "-er" and "-ir" verbs are the same conjugation, except when talking about **nosotros/nosotras**; in that case, use an "e" with "-er" verbs and an "i" with "-ir" verbs. 

Cool? Cool.

---

Here are the endings by themselves for "-ir" verbs:

|  **Pronoun**  |  **"-ir" Verb Endings**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **yo**  | -o |
| **tú** | -es |
| **él/ella** | -e | 
| **nosotros** | -imos |
| **ellos** | -en |
| **ustedes** | -en |

---

And lastly, here are a few of the words we'll go over in the next few drills:

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **vivir**  | to live |
| **escribir**  | to write |
| **decidir**  | to decide |
| **abrir**  | to open |
| **compartir**  | to share |
| **recibir**  | to receive |
| **definir**  | to define |

| **(ustedes) tienen** | you (all) have |

lessons.title: Red fish, blue fish
lessons.text:
We already talked about how grammatical gender applies to nouns. Now let's discuss how it works with adjectives.

The best way to think about how adjectives work in Spanish is that the form (gender and plurality) of an adjective *needs to match up to the noun it's modifying or describing*.

---

For this lesson, we'll focus on adjectives that end in "-o", which is one of the most common endings you'll encounter. 

These adjectives often have different forms they can take depending on whether the noun they're attached to is masculine or feminine.

For example:

- **el niño *pequeño*** - the small boy
- **la niña *pequeña*** - the small girl

---

This isn't too complicated, but there's a slight added complexity here. Not only do the adjectives change gender, *but they also become plural if the noun is plural*.

- **los niños *pequeños*** - the small boys
- **las niñas *pequeñas*** - the small girls

---

So these adjectives that end in "-o" have four different forms they can take depending on whether the noun they modify is masculine or feminine, singular or plural:

- **pequeño**
- **pequeña**
- **pequeños**
- **pequeñas**

---

This might seem weird, as we don't have anything like this in English. 

However, if you think of it as we mentioned above, ***that the adjective's form needs to match the noun it's modifying***, it's not too complicated.

---

You'll also notice that the adjectives here come *after* the nouns they modify. There are some exceptions to this that we'll talk about later, but for now, just know that adjectives in Spanish most often do come after the noun.

---

Here are a few more examples:

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
|  **un libro bueno**  | a good book |
|  **una revista buena**  | a good magazine |
|  **el hombre alto**  | the tall man |
|  **la mujer es alta**  | the woman is tall |
|  **los perros son rápidos** | the dogs are fast |
|  **las gatas rápidas** | the fast cats |
| **la comida es mala** | the food is bad |
| **el jugo es malo** | the juice is bad |
| **una pluma roja** | a red pen |
| **el carro blanco** | the white car |

lessons.title: Other endings
lessons.text:
**Adjectives ending with "-e"**

So far we've gone over adjectives that end in "-o," but there are other endings as well, many of which we've seen in earlier lessons. One of the more common endings for adjectives in Spanish is "-e,"  and these words behave as follows:

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
|  **un hombre inteligente**  | an intelligent man |
|  **una mujer inteligente**  | an intelligent woman |
|  **los hombres inteligentes**  | the intelligent men |
|  **las mujeres inteligentes**  | the intelligent women |

---

Just like their noun counterparts, adjectives that end in "-e" have a singular and plural form to match the nouns they modify (just add an "s" to create the plural), but they don't take different forms for gender.

---

Instead, they are the same whether they're modifying a masculine or feminine noun. So for these adjectives, there are only two versions to remember:

- **inteligente**
- **inteligentes**

---

**Adjectives ending in consonants**

There are also many adjectives that end in consonants, and these behave largely the same as those that end in "-e." They have a singular and plural form but don't change for grammatical gender.

---

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
|  **un trabajo difícil**  | a difficult job |
|  **una clase difícil**  | a difficult class |
|  **los juegos difíciles**  | the difficult games |
|  **las preguntas difíciles**  | the difficult questions |

---

Again, with these adjectives ending in consonants, there are only two forms to remember:

- **difícil**
- **difíciles**

We make the plural by adding "-es" to the end of the word. The only exception here is when the adjective ends in a "z", in which case the "z" changes to "c" before adding "-es."

For example, **feliz** (*happy*) becomes **felices**.

---

Here are a few examples to take a look at before we jump into practicing some new words!

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
|  **una casa grande**  | a big house |
|  **un libro verde**  | a green book |
|  **los doctores interesantes**  | the interesting doctors |
|  **las niñas felices**  | the happy girls |
|  **un actor popular**  | a popular actor |
|  **los carros azules**  | the blue cars |

**Nationality ending with "-o"**

Many adjectives that describe a person's nationality end in "-o" (mexicano, americano, italiano, etc.). These behave just like other "-o" adjectives, and they have forms for both gender and quantity:

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
|  **un hombre mexicano**  | a Mexican man |
|  **una mujer mexicana**  | a Mexican woman |
|  **los niños mexicanos**  | the Mexican children/boys |
|  **las niñas mexicanas**  | the Mexican girls |

---

**Nationality ending with a consonant**

Other adjectives for nationality end in consonants (español, francés, japonés), but they do not have the same rules as other adjectives ending in consonants. These nationality adjectives *do* have feminine forms to match up to feminine nouns.

---

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
|  **un hombre español**  | a Spanish man |
|  **una mujer española**  | a Spanish woman |
|  **los niños españoles**  | the Spanish children/boys |
|  **las niñas españolas**  | the Spanish girls |

---

**Nationality ending with "-e" or accented vowels**

The last (and less commonly used) group of adjectives for describing nationality end in either "-e" or a vowel with an accent (canadiense, iraquí). These both essentially follow the rules for regular adjectives ending in "-e." Neither has a feminine form, only changing to become plural.

---

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
|  **un hombre canadiense**  | a Canadian man |
|  **una mujer canadiense**  | a Canadian woman |
|  **los niños canadienses**  | the Canadian children/boys |
|  **las niñas canadienses**  | the Canadian girls |
|  **un hombre iraquí**  | an Iraqi man |
|  **una mujer iraquí**  | an Iraqi woman |
|  **los niños iraquíes**  | the Iraqi children/boys |
|  **las niñas iraquíes**  | the Iraqi girls |

lessons.title: Mucho y bueno
lessons.text:
Earlier, we said that most—but not all—adjectives in Spanish come *after* the nouns they're modifying (unlike English). Well, here come the exceptions!

---

Adjectives that have to do with **quantity** (including numbers) most often appear *before* the noun they're modifying.

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
|  **muchos libros**  | many books |
|  **mucha comida**  | a lot of food |
|  **pocos carros**  | few cars |
|  **unas sillas**  | some chairs |
|  **cinco minutos**  | five minutes |

---

**What comes before**

There are a couple of other common adjectives that often come before the nouns they modify. Bueno (*good*) and malo (*bad*) can both appear before nouns, which you'll see a lot.

---

When these adjectives come before a masculine noun, they drop the "-o" at the end of the word. Take a look at these examples:

- libro bueno -> **buen libro**
- comida buena -> **buena comida**
- libro malo -> **mal libro**
- comida mala -> **mala comida**

---

**Grande** (*big, large*) behaves a little differently when it comes before a noun. When it's *after* a noun, it means big, but *before* a noun, it changes to **gran** (if singular) and means *great.*

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
|  **un perro grande**  | a big dog |
|  **un gran perro**  | a great dog |
|  **un gran presidente**  | a great president |
|  **una gran mujer**  | a great woman |

---

**Best, worst, least**

The last category we'll talk about here is adjectives relating to a **value judgment** on a noun. If we're talking about the *best* or *worst* of a noun, then the adjective usually comes ahead of it.

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
|  **el mejor estudiante**  | the best student |
|  **la peor comida**  | the worst food |
|  **la menor cantidad**  | the least quantity |

lessons.title: Let's count to 10
lessons.text:
One of the most important things we can learn early on is how to count and express quantities of things. That's right, it's time to learn our numbers!

---

Let's start by learning zero through ten:

0\. cero
1\. uno
2\. dos
3\. tres
4\. cuatro
5\. cinco
6\. seis
7\. siete
8\. ocho
9\. nueve
10\. diez

---

The only real way to learn numbers well is to use them in context, rather than just counting up and down. So, let's get to practicing!

lessons.title: Teen spirit
lessons.text:
Now it's time to tackle the teens. Let's learn the numbers 11-19.

---

**Teens: 11-19**
11\. once
12\. doce
13\. trece
14\. catorce
15\. quince
16\. dieciséis
17\. diecisiete
18\. dieciocho
19\. diecinueve

---

You'll notice something curious here. The numbers 11-15 follow a different format than 16-19 (and, as we'll see in just a bit, all the other numbers up to 100).

16-19 should be pretty clear. We take **diez** (10) and add the regular number to it. When this happens, instead of being "diez y séis" (ten and six), it becomes **dieciséis** (sixteen).

---

So, why the different format with 11-15? Well, it's mostly for historical reasons. In fact, most of the romance languages have this quirk, because they all inherited it from Latin (thanks, Latin)...

That just means we have to memorize those five numbers. With a little practice, this should be no big deal.

---

For now, other than those few, remember that as we get to bigger numbers, we first count by tens, then add the proper single-digit number to the end. This way of thinking will come in handy in the next few sections.

lessons.title: Counting by tens
lessons.text:
Next, it's time to learn how to count by tens up to 100.

---

**Count by tens: 10-100**
10\. diez
20\. veinte
30\. treinta
40\. cuarenta
50\. cincuenta
60\. sesenta
70\. setenta
80\. ochenta
90\. noventa
100\. cien

---

Notice that, to make it easy on us, the numbers 30-90 all have the same ending: **-enta**. 

You can think of this as similar to English, where we have the ending "-ty" on the numbers 20-90 (twenty, thirty, forty, etc.).

---

Still, there's that pesky **veinte** (20) thrown in there to trip us up. That "e" on the end makes the twenties slightly different from other numbers as we count up higher, but we'll talk about that in just a few lessons.

For now, just make sure to memorize **veinte** and remember that it's different than the rest of the tens. It ends with an "-e" instead of "-enta."

lessons.title: Roaring twenties
lessons.text:
We mentioned previously that the twenties had an interesting quirk. Recall that with the numbers 16-19 we took two numbers (ten and a single digit) and smashed them into one (*diez y siete* -> **diecisiete**).

---

The twenties do the same thing, except all the way through from 21-29. So, they take the concept of saying "twenty and one" (veinte y uno) and combine them into one word: **veintiuno**. And the pattern continues with the rest.

---

20\. veinte
21\. veintiuno
22\. veintidos
23\. veintitres
24\. veinticuatro
25\. veinticinco
26\. veintiséis
27\. veintisiete
28\. veintiocho
29\. veintinueve

---

It's clear to see why this is the case. **Veinticinco** simply sounds like *veinte y cinco* said quickly, so it's a kind of shortcut.

The key thing to remember here (which is different from 30 and higher) is that the final "-e" in **veinte** changes to an "-i" and then you simply add the single digit to the end.

---

A quick note on veintiuno (twenty-one): just like other "ones," it changes form depending on the gender of the word it's describing.

For example:

**Un caballo, veintiún caballos**
*One horse, twenty-one horses*

**Una hora, veintiuna horas**
*One hour, twenty-one hours*

---

Pay attention to the masculine form here, it has a tricky accent mark: **veintiún**

lessons.title: Filling in the blanks
lessons.text:
For the rest of the numbers up to 99, they follow a consistent pattern. For example, thirty-one is simply **treinta y uno** (*literally, thirty and one*) and forty-five is **cuarenta y cinco** (*literally, forty and five*).

---

This simple pattern continues all the way to 99, without any exceptions. Finally, one rule without exception!

---

31\. treinta y uno
32\. treinta y dos
33\. treinta y tres
34\. treinta y cuatro
35\. treinta y cinco
36\. treinta y seis

---

37\. treinta y siete
38\. treinta y ocho
39\. treinta y nueve
40\. cuarenta
41\. cuarenta y uno
42\. cuarenta y dos... 
and so on, up to 99.

---

The easy way to remember this is that from thirty up, you use this formula: *tens number* + **y** + *single digit number*.

Easy peasy!

lessons.title: A thousand miles
lessons.text:
Now that we're familiar with the numbers up to one hundred, let's tackle the hundreds themselves, all the way up to a thousand.

---

100\. cien
200\. doscientos
300\. trescientos
400\. cuatrocientos
500\. quinientos
600\. seiscientos
700\. setecientos
800\. ochocientos
900\. novecientos
1000\. mil

---

The number **cien** (100) changes depending on whether it's by itself or has other numbers following it, but we'll talk about that shortly.

For now, just remember that, by itself, 100 is **cien**, even though it looks strangely shorter than the other hundreds.

---

For the rest of the hundreds, they mostly follow the same pattern: *base number (1-9)* + **-cientos**. However, you'll notice that a few of them change slightly, mostly just for the sake of easier, clearer pronunciation.

---

The first one of these is **quinientos** (500), which is by far the most different from the pattern. Not only does it not use *cinco* (5), but it also drops the "c" from "cientos."

If it helps, you can think of "quince" (*fifteen*) to associate **quinientos** with the number 5, but it might be best just to memorize this one.

---

The other two that are different are **setecientos** (700) and **novecientos** (900). You can see the similarities to "siete" (7) and "nueve" (9) here, but as we mentioned, they change slightly for clarity of pronunciation.

---

And let's not forget one thousand! In English numbers, we only see **mil** as a part of *million*, but don't let that confuse you. **Mil** in Spanish means *thousand*.

---

If it helps, you can think of a **millimeter**. A millimeter is one-**thousandth** of a meter, so **mil** is *one thousand*. Just a quick mnemonic for you as you go forth with your studies.

---

Speaking of studies, let's review these hundreds before moving on.

lessons.title: Irregular, but useful
lessons.text:
Even though Spanish verbs have a lot of conjugations, they're great in that most of them are regular and follow the rules, so we just need to know the root and can conjugate any form from there.

However, there are some really important basic verbs we haven't talked about yet, because they're irregular.

---

It's definitely annoying that these are some of the verbs you'll use most often in conversation, and yet they don't follow the rules, so you have to just memorize their conjugations (like **tener**—*to have*—which we went over earlier).

---

Fortunately, they're often at least *similar* to the regular conjugations, with just slight changes.

And because you'll use these often, you should have no trouble getting them down simply by using them! Let's go over a couple here, and then we'll circle back for more.

---

lessons.title: You're estar, kid
lessons.text:
We've talked previously about how the verb **ser** means "to be," but there's actually another verb that means "to be" in Spanish: **estar**. While these two both translate to "to be" in English, they're used in different situations and for different purposes.

Simply put, **ser** is used for *innate characteristics*, while **estar** is used for one's *current condition, location, and actions in progress* (progressive tense, which we'll discuss in a few lessons).

---

**Location**

Let's talk about location first.

- I **am** the president.
- I **am** in Mexico.

---

In English, these two sentences use the same verb: *to be*, conjugated as **am** here.

However, in Spanish, the first uses **ser** and the second uses **estar**:

- **Soy** el presidente.
- **Estoy** en México.

---

Anytime you want to talk about the location of something—whether it's an animate object (like a person or animal) or an inanimate object (like a building or car)—use **estar**.

---

**Current condition**

**Soy alto.**  
*I am tall.*

**Estoy feliz.**  
*I am happy.*

---

When referring to an *innate characteristic* of a person or thing, we use **ser**. You can think of ser as being more **permanent**, describing a trait that won't change over time (at the very least, not from day to day). 

This includes things like enduring physical traits (*tall, short, beautiful, ugly, thin, fat, strong, weak*) and occupation. 

---

Anytime the description is a noun (doctor, lawyer, teacher, student, etc.), you should use **ser.**

---

*Of course, someone may change their job or go from weak to strong over time, but these things don't really change from day to day, so we can think of them as being consistent across a longer period.*

---

**Estar**, on the other hand, has the connotation of a condition that is true *right now*, but is inherently temporary or liable to change before too long. 

This includes all sorts of things, like whether a person is happy or sad, or if they're healthy or sick.

---

This becomes clear when we ask "**¿Cómo estás?**" (*How are you?*). The reason we use **estar** rather than **ser** here is that we're really asking how the person is doing *right now*. 

So when you reply with something like "**Estoy bien**" (*I'm good*), you're describing your current condition *in the moment*.

---

Keep in mind that there are certain cases where you could use either ser or estar with the same adjective when describing someone. 

Using the example from above, we could actually say either **"Soy feliz"** or **"Estoy feliz."**

---

Even though these have the same literal translation (*I am happy*), they have different understood meanings:

- **Soy feliz** - *I am a generally happy person*
- **Estoy feliz** - *I am feeling happy right now*

---

Just remember the simple rule that **ser** is for long-lasting ("permanent") traits and **estar** is for a current condition, and you'll be good to go!

---

Like ser, estar is an irregular verb. Let's take a look at the conjugation chart and some examples before heading to practice.

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **estar**  | to be |
| (yo) **estoy** | I am |
| (tú) **estás** | you are |
| (él/ella) **está** | he/she is | 
| (nosotros) **estamos** | we are |
| (ellos) **están** | they are |

---

Examples:

**Ella es hermosa.**  
*She is beautiful.*

**Ella está cansada.**  
*She is tired.*

**Él es un doctor.**  
*He is a doctor.*

**Él está enfermo.**  
*He is sick.*

lessons.title: Practice makes progress
lessons.text:
Most courses would teach you past tense right about now, but not us! We'll cover past tense in the next section, but we figure that while we're talking about **estar**, we should discuss the **progressive tense** (because it's super useful).

---

Progressive tense is what we use to talk about actions that are *in progress*. It's the difference between "What do you do?" (present tense) and "What are you doing?" (progressive tense).

---

The plain old present tense is necessary, of course, but we often talk about things that are happening right now. 

For example, "I am eating cereal" and "I eat cereal" have completely different meanings.

---

To use the progressive tense in English, we add the ending **-ing** to the action verb: 

- eat -> **eating**
- run -> **running**
- speak -> **speaking**

and we precede the action with the verb "to be":

- I **am** eating
- She **is** running
- They **are**  speaking

---

Note here that the action word with the "-ing" ending (called the *participle* for those who care about grammatical terms) doesn't change at all. 

No matter who's performing the action, it remains the same. 

It's the "to be" in front of it that changes form depending on who is doing the action and when (past, present, future) it's taking place.

---

It's the same with Spanish! For the "to be" we use the verb **estar**, which changes form (conjugation) to tell us who we're talking about (and when, though we'll stick with the present for now), and the action word ("-ing" equivalent) stays the same no matter what. 

That means that there's less conjugation for us to learn. Yay!

---

In English, we add the ending "-ing" ending to verbs to create the progressive form. In Spanish, we conjugate the verb the same way we have before: removing the ending and adding a new one.

---

Let's take a look at the conjugations for our three types of Spanish verbs (-ar, -er, and -ir).

|  **Verb Type**  |  **New Ending**  |  **Example**  | 
| --------- | -------- | -------- |
| -ar  | -ando | hablando |
| -er  | -iendo | comiendo |
| -ir  | -iendo | escribiendo |

---

As you can see, these verbs always end in "-ndo," and there are only two conjugations to memorize, as the conjugation for "-er" and "-ir" verbs is the same! 

So to use the full progressive tense, all we do is add a conjugation of **estar** before this "-ndo" form, and we're rocking and rolling.

---

Here are some examples:

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **estoy comiendo** | I am eating |
| **estás comiendo** | you are eating |
| **(él/ella) está comiendo** | he/she is eating | 
| **estamos comiendo** | we are eating |
| **están comiendo** | they are eating |

---

And a few with different verbs:

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **estoy hablando** | I am talking/speaking |
| **estás escribiendo** | you are writing |
| **(él/ella) está corriendo** | he/she is running |
| **estamos cocinando** | we are cooking |
| **están estudiando** | they are studying |

Pretty useful, right?

lessons.title: It's in the past
lessons.text:
Unlike English, Spanish has two past tenses. These are called the **preterite** and the **imperfect**.

Simply put, the **preterite** is used for actions that are completed, that have a definite beginning and end, while the **imperfect** is used for actions that are more general in nature.

---

If this sounds a little confusing, don't worry (it is)! It'll become clearer as we practice. For now, to separate things out, we'll focus on the **preterite** (definite actions), and learn how to conjugate each of the regular verb types (-ar, -er, and -ir).

---

Later in this unit, we'll switch our attention to the **imperfect** (general actions) and do the same there.

Let's take a look at how to conjugate -ar verbs in the preterite!

---
Some examples:

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **hablar**  | to speak |
| **(yo) hablé** | I spoke |
| **(tú) hablaste** | you spoke |
| **(él/ella) habló** | he/she spoke | 
| **(nosotros) hablamos** | we spoke |
| **(ellos) hablaron** | they spoke |

---

The **preterite** is used only for actions that have a definite start and end. Those beginning and endpoints may or may not be stated explicitly. 

For example, if you're saying "I spoke with him about the llama.", you'd use the preterite, because your action is now complete (definite) and took place at a specific point in time, even though you didn't say it here.

---

You can think of the **preterite** as the regular past tense, since it encompasses what we would normally use in English, saying things like: "I ran," "she cooked," "the lawyer rode a purple giraffe in Nepal."

You know, just normal things you might say.

---

Let's take one last look at the endings for -ar verbs in the preterite:

|  **Pronoun**  |  **Ending**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **yo**  | -é |
| **tú** | -aste |
| **él/ella** | -ó | 
| **nosotros/nosotras** | -amos |
| **ellos/ellas** | -aron |

lessons.title: Those other endings
lessons.text:
Now that we know how the preterite works, and we've done some practice with -ar verbs, let's go over how to conjugate -er and -ir verbs in the preterite.

---

Fortunately for us, they're both the same!

*(Note: as long as they're regular. Remember that a bunch of -ir verbs in particular tend to be irregular. We'll talk in-depth about common irregular verbs later.)*

---

Since these two are the same, let's take a look at the endings first, and then some specific examples next.

|  **Pronoun**  |  **Ending**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **yo**  | -í |
| **tú** | -iste |
| **él/ella** | -ió | 
| **nosotros/nosotras** | -imos |
| **ellos/ellas** | -ieron |

---

And now for an example of an -er verb:

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **comer**  | to eat |
| **(yo) comí** | I ate |
| **(tú) comiste** | you ate |
| **(él/ella) comió** | he/she ate | 
| **(nosotros) comimos** | we ate |
| **(ellos) comieron** | they ate |

---

Here's one with an -ir verb:

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **vivir**  | to live |
| **(yo) viví** | I lived |
| **(tú) viviste** | you lived |
| **(él/ella) vivió** | he/she lived | 
| **(nosotros) vivimos** | we lived |
| **(ellos) vivieron** | they lived |

---

Remember the key point that the preterite is used for concrete actions.

lessons.title: This is highly irregular
lessons.text:
There are some important verbs that are irregular in the past tense, so (unfortunately) you just have to memorize their conjugations, just like we did with the present tense.

---

The bad news is that some of the most common verbs are irregular, but the good news (at least for the preterite form) is that they have some nice consistency between the conjugations, in that they generally follow the normal endings (they just happen to differ from their infinitives in weird ways).

---

Let's first take a look at **ser** (*to be*) and **ir** *(to go)*. In an excellent—but often confusing—turn of luck for us as learners, these two have the *exact same conjugations* in the preterite.

---

|  **Pronoun**  |  **ser** *(to be)*  |  **ir** *(to go)*  | 
| --------- | -------- | -------- |
| **yo**  | fui | fui |
| **tú** | fuiste | fuiste |
| **él/ella** | fue | fue | 
| **nosotros/nosotras** | fuimos | fuimos |
| **ellos/ellas** | fueron | fueron |

---

So, how do we tell these apart, then? For the most part, context!

**Fuimos estudiantes.**
*We were students.*

**Fuimos a la playa.**
*We went to the beach.*

---

Not too crazy, right?

*Note: if you're going **to** somewhere, you use the preposition "a" between the verb (ir) and the place you're going or went. For example, "Fuiste **a** la universidad" (You went **to** the university) or "Voy **a** la tienda" (I go **to** the store).*

lessons.title: Increasing irregularity
lessons.text:
The next two verbs we'll look at are **decir** *(to say)* and **hacer** *(to do)*. Here's a quick trick to make sense of the next chart: imagine that the *infinitives* for these verbs (the dictionary forms ending in -ir and -er) change before they are conjugated.

---

In other words, imagine that *decir* becomes **dijir** and *hacer* becomes **hicer**. Then, if you conjugate those new made-up infinitives using the regular rules for the preterite, you'll have everything correct!

---

*Note: we don't recommend actually memorizing these imaginary infinitives, as that could get confusing, but if it helps you conjugate the verbs in this form, feel free to use them! Otherwise, just forget we ever said anything about it.*

---

*Second note: pay special attention to the singular third person (él/ella) form for **hacer**, which becomes **hizo** in the preterite, thanks to the sound-changing rules for Spanish.*

---

|  **Pronoun**  |  **decir** *(to say)*  |  **hacer** *(to do)*  | 
| --------- | -------- | -------- |
| **yo**  | dije | hice |
| **tú** | dijiste | hiciste |
| **él/ella** | dijo | hizo | 
| **nosotros/nosotras** | dijimos | hicimos |
| **ellos/ellas** | dijeron | hicieron |

---

Here are a couple of examples:

**¿Qué dijiste?**
*What did you say?*

**Hice toda la tarea.**
*I did all of the homework.*

---

As a bonus for this lesson, let's quickly learn how **ver** *(to see)* works in the preterite, mainly because it's nothing too crazy:

|  **Pronoun**  |  **ver** *(to see)*  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **yo**  | vi |
| **tú** | viste |
| **él/ella** | vio | 
| **nosotros/nosotras** | vimos |
| **ellos/ellas** | vieron |

---

You might look at that chart and think, "Wait, what's irregular about that? It looks completely normal!"

Don't worry, we did the same thing. Essentially, the only irregular thing about **ver** is that it doesn't use the accented characters. So instead of **ví** and **vió** (which it would normally be), we get **vi** and **vio**.

lessons.title: Cat-like reflexives
lessons.text:
When the *subject* performing an action and the *object* receiving that action are the same, we call that the **reflexive**. In English, we often use the -self words for this:

myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves

---
Let's take these two similar sentences as an example:

**I see myself** vs. **I see the dog**

**I see myself** *is* reflexive, because the subject and object are the same (me), whereas **I see the dog** is *not* reflexive, because the subject (me) and the object (the dog) are different.

---

You've probably seen the reflexive before. When introducing yourself and telling someone your name, you say **Me llamo [your name].**

**Llamar** means *to call*, so when you say **Me llamo Juan**, you're literally saying **I call myself Juan**, though because that sounds odd in English, we translate it as **My name is Juan.**

---

Here are a few more examples with the literal translations:

**¿Cómo te llamas?**
*What's your name?*
*(literally: What do you call yourself?)*

**Me llamo Rosa.**
*My name is Rosa.*
*(literally: I call myself Rosa.)*

---

In Spanish, this reflexive form is used far more broadly than in English. You'll see this more clearly in the coming examples, but anytime the action being performed is directed back toward the subject, we use the reflexive.

This applies even if the object being acted on is just a *part* of the subject, like washing one's face or brushing one's teeth.

---

Where English has the -self pronouns for this kind of action, Spanish has its own set of **reflexive pronouns**:

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **me**  | myself |
| **te**  | yourself |
| **se**  | himself, herself, itself |
| **nos**  | ourselves |
| **se**  | themselves, yourselves |

---

Let's look at how these are used in practice:

**Me siento en la cama.**
*I sit on the bed.*
*(literally: I seat myself on the bed)*

**Él se baña.**
*He takes a bath.*
*(literally: He bathes himself.)*

**Nos cepillamos los dientes.**
*We brush our teeth.*
*(literally: We brush the teeth for ourselves.)*

---

*Note: when you're talking about parts of the body, use the definite article (el, la) rather than the possessive.*

*For example: "Me cepillo **el** pelo" is **correct**. "Me cepillo **mi** pelo" is incorrect.*

---

Keep in mind that, going forward, we will be using natural-sounding translations that keep the meaning in English, not the literal translations. So, **Me ducha** will be **I take a shower**, not **I give myself a shower.**

lessons.title: More than one
lessons.text:
Remember the **infinitive** form of a verb? That's what we call the form you'd see in the dictionary, like **ser** (*to be*), **comer** (*to eat*), **hablar** (*to speak*), etc.

Well, for reflexive verbs, that infinitive includes the third-person reflexive pronoun on the end. For example: **llamarse** (*to call oneself*), **bañarse** (*to take a bath*), and **lavarse** (*to wash oneself*).

---

This is good to know, but it becomes especially relevant when there's more than one verb in a sentence. In these cases, you have two options: to include the pronoun ahead of the conjugated verb, or to place it at the end of the infinitive. 

Take a look at these sentences, which are identical in meaning:

**Me quiero bañar.**
**Quiero bañarme.**
*I want to take a bath.*

---

Here are a few more examples illustrating the concept:

**Nos queremos ver.**
**Queremos vernos.**
*We want to see ourselves.*

**Él se necesita lavar las manos.**
**Él necesita lavarse las manos.**
*He needs to wash his hands.*

**Ella no se puede dormir.**
**Ella no puede dormirse.**
*She can't fall asleep.*

lessons.title: One exception
lessons.text:
There's one key verb here that doesn't really play by the rules of the reflexive, and that is **ir** (*to go*). Its reflexive form is **irse**, and it means *to leave*.

**Yo voy a la oficina.**
*I go to the office.*

**Me voy de la oficina.**
*I leave from the office.*

---

There are a few other verbs that have slight changes of meaning when they switch their infinitive forms, but none are different enough to worry about here.

units.description: Let's add some spice to our actions with adverbs!

lessons.title: Slowly I Turned
lessons.text:
Step by step and inch by inch, we're getting there, so pat yourself on the back for making it to Intermediate! Now we move on to simple adverbs, which is a good way to ease into some of the more challenging aspects of Spanish.

---

Expressing most simple Spanish adverbs falls into two camps: adding **-mente** to the end of feminine singular adjectives, or using the preposition **con** before the singular form of the noun. Let's take a look at some examples. First, **-mente** which you can think of as the **-ly** ending in English.

---

**rápida** -> **rápidamente**
*quick* -> *quickly*

**lenta** -> **lentamente**
*slow* -> *slowly*

**facil** -> **facilmente**
*easy* -> *easily*

**desesperada** -> **desesperadamente**
*desperate* -> *desperately*

**final** -> **finalmente**
*final* -> *finally*

---

*Note: If the adjective has an accent, the adverb will as well, such as in the previous example of rápida/rápidamente*

---

If that ever trips you up, there's a handy failsafe, which is the **con** + noun format. This can be used if you're having trouble recalling or spelling the feminine version of an adjective, or simply because certain adverbs can be a bit awkward when following the **-mente** rule.

---

pacientemente = **con paciencia**
*patiently*

respetuosamente = **con respeto**
*respectfully*

inteligentemente = **con inteligencia**
*intelligently*

dulcemente = **con dulzura**
*sweetly*

frecuentemente = **con frecuencia**
*frequently*

---

As we mentioned earlier, these two rules cover *most* simple adverbs, not all. Some adverbs simply don't have a pattern, such as **nunca** (never) and **a veces** (sometimes), which means you'll have to commit them to memory.

---

Never fear, though, we'll be covering some of these adverbs in the next lesson and beyond.

lessons.title: Up, Down, and Around
lessons.text:
Now that you know some of the rules regarding adverbs, we're ready to disregard them completely as we move on to some of the loose-cannon adverbs that don't play by the rules. With these, you'll simply have to commit them to memory, but through practice it'll become second-nature in no time. We'll start with adverbs of place here.

---

Adverbs of place are usually used when answering the question of "Where?" as it provides information on location. In English, these would be words such as here, there, above, and below. Let's take a look.

---

|  **Adverb**  |  **English**  |
| -------- | -------- |
|  **aquí**  |  here  |
|  **acá**  |  over here  |
|  **allí**  |  there  |
|  **allá**  |  over there  |
|  **cerca**  |  near  |
|  **lejos**  |  far  |

---

|  **Adverb**  |  **English**  |
| -------- | -------- |
|  **delante**  |  in front  |
|  **detrás**  |  in rear  |
|  **encima**  |  on top  |
|  **debajo**  |  underneath  |
|  **dentro**  |  in  |
|  **fuera**  |  out  |

---

|  **Adverb**  |  **English**  |
| -------- | -------- |
|  **adelante**  |  ahead  |
|  **atrás**  |  behind  |
|  **arriba**  |  up/above  |
|  **abajo**  |  down/below  |
|  **adentro**  |  inside  |
|  **afuera**  |  outside  |

---

*Note: As you've probably noticed, a few of these words are extremely similar, both in spelling and definition. We've tried to give you the best context (i.e. **detrás** meaning in rear as it applies more to placement and **atrás** meaning behind as it applies more to movement) but the words are highly interchangeable, so don't lose too much sleep over it!*

The finish line is in sight! You've learned the rules that *most* adverbs follow, as well as adverbs of place, time, quantity, and manner, and now we're going to wrap things up with commonly used adverbial phrases.

lessons.title: Back to the future
lessons.text:
So far, we've covered the present tense, present progressive, and past tense. Now, it's time to talk about the future.

---

So here's the tricky bit: Spanish has two future tenses. The first is the **informal future**, so-called because it actually uses the present tense of the verb **ir** (*to go*), combined with another verb, rather than having its own special conjugation.

This **informal future** is used far more often than its counterpart, the **simple future**, so we'll focus on it first and circle back to the simple future later in this unit.

---

Since we're using the present tense conjugations of **ir** (*to go*), this method is really straightforward. It's simply the correct conjugation of **ir** + **a** + *verb infinitive*.

For example:

**Ella va a correr.**
*She is going to run.*

**Voy a cocinar mañana.**
*I'm going to cook tomorrow.*

---

In case you need to brush up on the conjugations for **ir**, here they are in this context:

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **ir**  | to go |
| **(yo) voy a comer** | I am going to eat |
| **(tú) vas a comer** | you are going to eat |
| **(él/ella) va a comer** | he/she is going to eat | 
| **(nosotros) vamos a comer** | we are going to eat |
| **(ellos) van a comer** | they are going to eat |

---

Go ahead and take a look at these examples of the **informal future**, then let's get to practicing!

**El presidente va a hablar.**
*The president is going to speak.*

**Ellos van a nadar.**
*They are going to swim.*

**Vamos a leer.**
*We are going to read.*

lessons.title: The future is simple
lessons.text:
Okay, so now that we know how to use the **informal future** to express what we *are going* to do, let's learn how to conjugate verbs for the **simple future**.

*Note: keep in mind that **informal future** (using **ir + a + infinitive**) is used more often than the simple future, so when in doubt, default to the informal.*

---

You can think of the **simple future** as just a different way to say the same thing. For example, take a look at these two sentences in English:

**I am going to eat the food.**

**I will eat the food.**

There might be a slight difference in connotation, but they basically have the same meaning, right? The same is true of these two methods of expressing the future in Spanish.

---

Let's add the Spanish translations to the previous example:

**Voy a comer la comida.**
*I am going to eat the food.*

**Comeré la comida.**
*I will eat the food.*

Not too crazy, right?

---

Let's look at the endings for the simple future conjugation. Unlike the present and past tense, we simply add these endings to the end of the *infinitive form* of the verb. 

Oh, and these endings apply to all three regular verb groups, which makes it easy for us!

|  **Pronoun**  |  **Ending**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **yo**  | -é |
| **tú** | -ás |
| **él/ella** | -á | 
| **nosotros/nosotras** | -emos |
| **ellos/ellas** | -án |

---

And here's an example using the word **estudiar** (*to study*):

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **estudiar**  | to study |
| **(yo) estudiaré** | I will study |
| **(tú) estudiarás** | you will study |
| **(él/ella) estudiará** | he/she will study | 
| **(nosotros) estudiaremos** | we will study |
| **(ellos) estudiarán** | they will study |

Okay, let's practice!
