lessons.title: Informal vs. simple
lessons.text:
Now that we know how to use both the **informal future** and the **simple future**, we need to understand when we should use each one. 

Let's talk about the context for using these two different methods.

---

You can think of the informal future *ir + a + infinitive*) as covering any action that's going to happen in the **relatively near future**.

**Voy a viajar a Japón el próximo mes.**
*I'm going to travel to Japan next month.*

**Él va a beber cerveza.**
*He is going to drink beer.*

**El estudiante va a estudiar español.**
*The student is going to study Spanish.*

---

Essentially, if what you want to say in English begins with "I'm going to...", you can use the informal future. This is by far the more common way to express things you're going to do in everyday life.

---

The **simple future**, in contrast, is used for actions that will take place further in the future.

**Viajaré a Colombia el año que viene.**
*I'll travel to Colombia next year.*

**Después de la universidad, él será un doctor.**
*After university, he'll be a doctor.*

---

The **simple future** is also used in cases where you want to express curiosity without asking a direct, pointed question in the present tense. In English, these kinds of sentences can be translated in multiple ways, meaning essentially the same thing and having the same connotation of curiosity.

---

Take a look at these examples of expressing curiosity with the simple future:

**¿Quién será eso?**
*Who could that be?*
*I wonder who that is.*

**¿Dónde estarán los niños?**
*Where could the children be?*
*I wonder where the children are.*

---

The third—and final—primary use of the **simple future** is to talk about probability:

**Ella estará estudiando.**
*She is probably studying.*

**Ellos comerá pescado.**
*They probably eat fish.*

---

Keep in mind that there are other ways to express curiosity and probability (using words like **preguntarse** (*to wonder*) and **probablamente** (*probably*)), but as this is one key use of the **simple future** that differentiates it from the **informal future**, we wanted to introduce it here.

---

To review: the **informal future** is the more commonly used form, and it generally refers to actions happening in the relatively near future.

The **simple future** is used for events further out, as well as to express curiosity and probability regarding current situations and actions.

units.title: Imperfect Past Tense
units.description: This pack covers the imperfect past tense, so you can learn how to talk about things you used to do.

lessons.title: Imperfection
lessons.text:
If you'll remember back to the Beginner 6 pack, we learned how to talk about completed, definite actions in the past using the **preterite** form, but there's another form of past tense in Spanish called the **imperfect**. 

---

The **imperfect** is used for actions that occurred in the past but are either:
1. not seen as being completed or finished, and/or
2. do not have a definite beginning and end.

Let's take a look at the different uses for the imperfect tense with some practical examples.

---

*Note: we'll talk about the conjugations of all these verbs throughout this pack, but this lesson is just using examples to illustrate the cases where we would use the imperfect. So don't worry if the conjugations look a little strange right now, they'll all make sense soon.*

---

**Things you used to do**

The imperfect tense is used to talk about past actions that were habitual or recurring, meaning that they happened more than once, most likely at a semi-regular interval.

In English, this will often translate as something that one "used to do" or "would do" in the past.

---

Here are a few examples:

**Comíamos juntos cada día.**
*We used to eat together every day.*

**Hablabamos en la escuela.**
*We used to talk in school.*

---

**Past dates and times**

We also use the imperfect to speak about dates and times in the past.

**Eran las once de la noche.**
*It was eleven at night.*

**Era el cuatro de julio.**
*It was the fourth of July.*

---

**How old you were**

The imperfect can be used to talk about how old someone was at a point in the past.

**Yo tenía diez años.**
*I was ten years old.*

**Los elefantes tenían tres años.**
*The elephants were three years old.*

As per usual, there are a few irregular verbs that don't quite follow the rules for conjugation in the imperfect, so we just have to memorize them.

Fortunately, unlike most other conjugations, the imperfect only has three irregular verbs, which makes our job much easier!

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  |

| **(nosotros) íbamos** | we went |

*Note: don't miss the accent over the í on the first person plural (íbamos)*

| **(ellos) eran** | they was |

| **(tú) veías** | you saw |
| **(él/ella) veía** | he/she saw | 
| **(nosotros) veíamos** | we saw |
| **(ellos) veían** | they saw |

units.title: Conditional Tense
units.description: Would you like to learn about the conditional tense? You're in luck, this pack is all about it!

lessons.title: On one condition...
lessons.text:
The **conditional tense** is exactly what it sounds like: it gives us a way to talk about things that hypothetically *would* happen, if a certain condition is met.

Sometimes that condition is stated explicitly (i.e. I would go to the movies if I had money), and sometimes it's not stated at all (i.e. I would be interested).

---

In the most basic terms, you can think of the Spanish conditional tense as very similar to using "would" in English.

---

For example, here are a couple of basic uses of the conditional:

**Compraría ese libro, pero no tengo dinero.**
*I would buy that book, but I don't have money.*

**Me interesaría aprender más sobre México.**
*I would be interested in learning more about Mexico.*

---

Similar to the *simple future* tense, to conjugate the **conditional tense** we add the corresponding endings to the *infinitive* form of the verb. In other words, no need to drop the -ar, -er, or -ir.

Oh, and all three verb groups use the same endings!

---

Here are the endings for the conditional tense:

|  **Pronoun**  |  **Ending**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **yo**  | -ía |
| **tú** | -ías |
| **él/ella** | -ía | 
| **nosotros/nosotras** | -íamos |
| **ellos/ellas** | -ían |

---

Here's an example using the word **estudiar** (*to study*):

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **estudiar**  | to study |
| **(yo) estudiaría** | I would study |
| **(tú) estudiarías** | you would study |
| **(él/ella) estudiaría** | he/she would study | 
| **(nosotros) estudiaríamos** | we would study |
| **(ellos) estudiarían** | they would study |

---

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  | 
| --------- | -------- |
| **ser**  | to be |
| **(yo) sería** | I would be |
| **(tú) serías** | you would be |
| **(él/ella) sería** | he/she would be | 
| **(nosotros) seríamos** | we would be |
| **(ellos) serían** | they would be |

lessons.title: It would be irregular
lessons.text:
As with most of the other tenses, there are a few key verbs that are irregular in the conditional. In this case, the *endings* that we've learned stay the same while the *infinitive* changes.

---

These irregular conjugations fit neatly into two groups (with two left over), so let's take a look at these one at a time. We'll cover the first group in this lesson.

---

In the first group, we simply remove the last vowel in the verb and add the proper conditional ending. 

For example, **saber** (*to know*) would become **sabría** in the first and third person.

---

|  **Spanish**  |  **English**  |

| **saber**  | to know |
| **(yo) sabría** | I would know |
| **(tú) sabrías** | you would know |
| **(él/ella) sabría** | he/she would know | 
| **(nosotros) sabríamos** | we would know |
| **(ellos) sabrían** | they would know |

---

|  **Infinitive**  | **Meaning** | **Conditional**  | 
| --------- | -------- | -------- |
| saber  | to know | **sabría** |
| poder  | to be able to | **podría** |
| caber  | to fit | **cabría** |
| haber  | to have/to exist | **habría** |

units.title: Past Participle
units.description: We cover a lot of ground in this pack, introducing you to the past participle and how it can be used in the present and past perfect tenses.

lessons.title: I don't know the meaning
lessons.text:
The past participle is a fairly simple and quite useful verb form. It's something you likely use every day in English, though the name might sound unfamiliar.

For this lesson, we'll be talking about its use as an adjective, and later in the unit, we'll dive into how it can be combined with another verb to create the perfect tense.

---

In English, you can think of the past participle as the **-ed** form of a verb, as it's often conjugated by adding **-ed** or **-d** to the end of a verb in English.

For example, *constructed*, *brushed*, *opened*, and *closed* are all past participles.

---

Of course, English being English, there are almost more exceptions than rules, as some more examples will illustrate: *written*, *driven*, *broken*, *seen*, *built*.

*Note: Though some of these conjugations are the same as the regular past tense (particularly the **-ed** ones), the past participle is distinct from the past tense (saw vs. seen, wrote vs. written)*

---

To conjugate the past participle in Spanish, we remove the infinitive ending (-ar, -er, or -ir) and add **-ado** to -ar verbs, or **-ido** to -er and -ir verbs.

---

Here are a few examples:

**cerrar** -> **cerrado**
*to close* -> *closed*

**construir** -> **construido**
*to build* -> *built*

---

Alone, a past participle can be used as an adjective. For example: 

**El restaurante está cerrado.**
*The restaurant is closed.*

**La casa está terminada.**
*The house is finished.*

**El juguete perdido**
*The lost toy*

---

Just like all other adjectives, the past participle has to match up to the noun it's modifying or describing in both gender and plurality.

El restaurante está **cerrado**.
*The restaurant is closed.*

La ventana está **cerrada**.
*The window is closed.*

Los cines están **cerrados**.
*The movie theaters are closed.*

Las puertas están **cerradas**.
*The doors are closed.*

---

Remember that using the past participle as an adjective is just one of several uses that we'll discuss throughout this pack. With that in mind, let's practice!

lessons.title: Irregular, as always
lessons.text:
As per usual, there are a number of important verbs that are irregular in the past participle. Let's look at a few of the ones you'll see most often.

**abrir** -> **abierto**
*to open* -> *opened*

**cubrir** -> **cubierto**
*to cover* -> *covered*

**decir** -> **dicho**
*to say* -> *said*

---

**escribir** -> **escrito**
*to write* -> *written*

**hacer** -> **hecho**
*to do* -> *done*

**ver** -> **visto**
*to see* -> *seen*

---

**romper** -> **roto**
*to break* -> *broken*

**morir** -> **muerto**
*to die* -> *dead*

**volver** -> **vuelto**
*to return* -> *returned*

---

There aren't any solid rules around forming these irregular past participles, so they're just ones you'll have to memorize. Don't worry, we'll see them quite a bit throughout the rest of this pack as we practice!

**La comida fue descubierto.**

**El libro fue escrito por el autor.**

**La tarea es realizada por el estudiante.**
*The homework is done by the student.*

lessons.title: Perfectly balanced
lessons.text:
In Spanish, we can combine the verb **haber** (*to have*) with the past participle to create the perfect tenses. In this lesson, we'll talk about the **present perfect**.

---

This should look familiar in English, as we use the perfect tense to talk about actions that are fully completed. In this case, we're talking about a state that refers to the present, to right now:

I **have eaten** the candy.

The student **has studied** for her test.

The kids **have played** that game.

---

The present perfect functions exactly the same in Spanish:

**He comido** los dulces.
*I **have eaten** the candy.*

El estudiante **ha estudiado** para el examen.
*The student **has studied** for the test.*

Los niños **han jugado** ese juego.
*The kids **have played** that game.*

---

Since we already know how to use the past participle, all we need to learn is how to conjugate **haber**.

| --------- | -------- |

| **(yo) he** | I have |
| **(tú) has** | you have |
| **(él/ella) ha** | he/she has | 
| **(nosotros) hemos** | we have |
| **(ellos) han** | they have |

---

*Note: as per usual, because each conjugation is unique, we can generally leave off the pronoun before the verb.*

That's where the **past perfect** tense comes in.

Just like the present perfect, the **past perfect** uses the verb **haber** + *past participle*, so all we have to do is learn the past tense conjugation for haber:

units.title: Subjunctive Mood
units.description: I hope you're in a good mood, because we're about to cover the subjunctive. Prepare for a wild ride filled with desire, doubt, action, and strongly worded opinions.

lessons.title: I'm not in the mood
lessons.text:
This pack is all about the subjunctive. With the subjunctive, we're leaving the comfort of the **tense** and venturing into the unknown world of the **mood**.

Okay, it's not that unknown. We technically have the subjunctive in English too, and it'll sound pretty familiar to you start working with it. We'll try to keep it simple.

---

First of all, what's the difference between a *tense* and a *mood*? At the most basic level, a *tense* lets us know when something is taking place (past, present, future, ongoing, etc.), while a *mood* expresses how the speaker feels about an action.

---

We've been using only one mood up to this point: the **indicative**. The indicative mood is used to report or declare something that is objective or certain, as well as to ask questions. It's the most commonly used mood, and should be your default.

For example:

**Yo sé que eres estudiante.**
*I know that you are a student.*

**¿Quieres ir al cine?**
*Do you want to go to the movie theater?*

---

In contrast, the **subjunctive** mood is used for *subjectivity*, anything that's not certain or objective. This includes things like desires, opinions, and uncertainty.

**Espero qué él hable inglés.**
*I hope that he speaks English.*

**Ella quiere que su hijo la llame.**
*She wants her son to call her.*

---

So, when deciding whether to use the indicative or the subjunctive, you can think of it in very simple terms:

certainty and objectivity = **indicative**

uncertainty and subjectivity = **subjunctive**

---

That's the main gist of it, but of course we'll give you some examples throughout this pack of when exactly you should use the subjunctive.

Broadly, the subjunctive fits into these situations:

1. Desire
2. Doubt
3. Uncompleted actions
4. Impersonal opinions

---

First things first, let's learn how to conjugate the subjunctive and use it to express our desires!

lessons.title: One rule to rule them all
lessons.text:
Before we talk about our first use case for the subjunctive, let's learn how to conjugate it.

---

To conjugation verbs in the subjunctive, we start with what's called the **yo** form of the verb, which is the verb conjugated into the first-person present tense (hence the **yo**). 

Then, we drop the -o at the end to get the *stem*. Lastly, we add the proper ending.

---

For example:

- hablar -> hablo -> habl- -> **hable**
- escribir -> escribo -> escrib- -> **escriba**

We've conjugated a lot of verbs, so this should be old hat by now. The only difference is that we begin with the **yo** form instead of the infinitive.

---

For many verbs, the stem of the present tense *yo* will look exactly the same as the infinitive stem, so why make things more complicated? 

Well, it helps to think of subjunctive conjugation this way, because this one rule covers both regular and irregular verbs (with a couple of exceptions that we'll talk about later).

---

In other words, starting with the **yo** form and then dropping the -o works for verbs that have irregular **yo** forms as well. We just roll with it and add the proper ending from there, which makes everything simpler.

- comer -> como -> com- -> **coma**
- querer -> quiero -> quier- -> **quiera**

---

Okay, so what are the correct endings for the subjunctive? Well, here they are:

|  **pronoun** |  **-ar**  |  **-er, -ir**  | 
| --------- | -------- | -------- |
| yo | **-e** | **-a** |
| tú | **-es** | **-as** |
| él/ella | **-e** | **-a** |
| nosotros | **-emos** | **-amos** |
| ellos | **-en** | **-an** |

---

Here are some examples for each ending with verbs that have regular **yo** forms:

|  **hablar** |  **comer**  |  **escribir**  | 
| --------- | -------- | -------- |
| hable | coma | escriba |
| hables | comas | escribas |
| hable | coma | escriba |
| hablemos | comamos | escribamos |
| hablen | coman | escriban |

---

Finally, here are a few examples of verbs with irregular **yo** forms.

|  **pronoun** |  **tener**  |  **querer**  | 
| --------- | -------- | -------- |
| yo | **tenga** | **quiera** |
| tú | **tengas** | **quieras** |
| él/ella | **tenga** | **quiera** |
| nosotros | **tengamos** | **quieramos** |
| ellos | **tengan** | **quieran** |

---

For once, it's nice to see that there's a method to the madness when it comes to irregular verbs, and that there are rules we can follow instead of just memorizing them.

Let's talk about how the subjunctive is used to express desire, and then get some practice.

lessons.title: Hopes and dreams
lessons.text:
All right, so we know how to conjugate the subjunctive now, but when should we use it?

The first case is when expressing a **desire** or **wish**.

---

Earlier on, we said that the subjunctive was used in cases of *uncertainty*. When expressing a desire, there is an inherent element of uncertainty. We're *hoping* that something happens, but we can't be *absolutely certain* that it will.

---

In this case, sentences often break out into two clauses, one indicative and one subjunctive. The indicative clause reports what it is the speaker is doing (hoping, wanting, suggesting, etc.), while the subjunctive clause tells us what the speaker is hoping for, something that has not yet happened and is therefore uncertain.

---
Take this sentence, for example: I hope **that my sister goes to the store**.

The first clause (*I hope*) is indicative because I am certain that I am *hoping* for something. It's a fact. However, I'm not certain of what my sister will do. I may *really want* her to go to the store, but until she does, I can't report it as a fact. There's an element of uncertainty.

---

Here are a few more examples that show where we use the indicative and where we use the subjunctive.

I hope **that he speaks Spanish**.

The doctor wants **his patients to be healthy**.

I prefer **that you play outside**.

The teacher suggests **that the student read the book**.

---

To put it in simple terms, the subject's action uses the indicative mood, while the outcome they desire uses the subjunctive. Let's see the previous sentences with their Spanish translations.

**Espero que él hable español.**
*I hope that he speaks Spanish.*

**El doctor quiere que sus pacientes estén sanos.**
*The doctor wants his patients to be healthy.*

---

**Prefiero que juegues afuera.**
*I prefer that you play outside.*

**La maestra sugiere que el estudiante lea el libro.**
*The teacher suggests that the student read the book.*

---

Here are a few *desire* words that will likely be paired with a subjunctive clause.

- esperar - to hope
- querer - to want
- preferir - to prefer
- insistir - to insist (on)
- recomendar - to recommend
- sugerir - to suggest

---

Two important notes here:

1. This list is far from exhaustive. Part of the tricky nature of the subjunctive is that it's not always clear when exactly to use it. The rule of thumb is that if there's any element of uncertainty, something outside your control that you can't report as an absolute fact, then the subjunctive would likely be appropriate.

---

2. Most of the verbs in this *desire* section are paired with **que** (*that*), as in "I hope that..." or "She insists that..."

You'll see this more in practice. Speaking of practice, let's get to it!

lessons.title: Outlaws & renegades
lessons.text:
We've already talked about how *most* irregular verbs fit nicely into the subjunctive with no special consideration.

But, as per usual, there are a few important verbs that like to do their own thing, so let's talk about those outlaws.

---

There are six verbs we'll talk about here: 
- **ir** (*to go*)
- **ser** (*to be*)
- **estar** (the other *to be*)
- **dar** (*to give*)
- **saber** (*to know*)
- **haber** (*to exist*)

---

Let's look at the first three, **ir**, **ser**, and **estar**:

---

| dé | sepa | haya |
| des | sepas | hayas |
| dé | sepa | haya |
| demos | sepamos | hayamos |
| den | sepan | hayan |

---

lessons.title: I seriously doubt that
lessons.text:
The second main way we use the subjunctive is when expressing doubt, which, by its definition, has an element of uncertainty.

---

Just like when talking about desire, there are a few key verb phrases that give us a clue that we should use the subjunctive. Here are a few of the most common:

- **dudar** - to doubt
- **no creer** - to not believe
- **no estar seguro** - to not be sure
- **no pensar** - to not think
- **no estar convencido** - to not be convinced

---

Notice all of these verbs (except for *dudar*) are only used as negatives in relation to the subjunctive. If we were to use the positive, we would actually use the *indicative* mood.

For example, while **No creo que...** (*I don't believe that...*) has an element of doubt and uncertainty, **Creo que...** (*I believe that...*) is quite the opposite, showing that we're sure of something.

---

In addition to these verbs, there are a few other statements that indicate the use of the subjunctive:

- **es dudoso que** - it is doubtful that
- **es improbable que** - it’s unlikely/improbable that
- **es posible que** - it’s possible that

---

We could put a much longer list of examples here, but these are the most key phrases that will let you know the subjunctive should be coming up in the following clause.

You know the rules now, so use your best judgment: any phrase that introduces an element of doubt or ignorance (not being totally sure of something) should be paired with the subjunctive.

---

For other specific examples, we'll just have to practice and see them in use!

lessons.title: I feel incomplete
lessons.text:
As we established when talking about desire, actions that are not yet completed have an inherent degree of uncertainty, as we can't be *absolutely sure* that they will come to pass.

---

These *uncompleted action* sentences usually have an element of time (**when** the action is completed, something will happen) or a condition (**if** the action is completed, something will happen).

---

- something will happen **when the action is completed**
- something will happen **if the action is completed**

The first parts of our examples here are the indicative clauses, as we are making the objective statement that something will happen. The second, bolded parts are the subjunctive clauses, relying on the assumption that the action will take place.

---

Let's look at some more concrete examples:

I will read the book **as soon as he finishes it**.
*I will certainly read the book, assuming he finishes reading it first.*

My brother will watch TV **while I cook dinner**.
*My brother will watch for sure, as long as I actually cook dinner.*

---

There are a few key phrases that let us know we're talking about an uncompleted action. These ones each have a conditional element:

- **a menos que** - unless
- **en caso de que** - in case
- **con tal (de) que** - provided that

---

And these have an element of time:

- **antes (de) que** - before
- **después (de) que** - after
- **mientras que** - while
- **hasta que** - after
- **tan pronto como** - as soon as

---

The key takeaway here is that all these phrases contain either an element of time or a condition. In other words, they rely on the uncompleted action being completed before the statement will come true.

---

This rule can help guide as you determine whether you should use the subjunctive out there in the real world. But until then, let's practice!

lessons.title: Judgment call
lessons.text:
The last situation we'll talk about in this pack is what's called an *impersonal opinion*. But wait, aren't all opinions personal?

Technically, yes. They do belong to a person. Perhaps a clearer distinction here would be to say that we're talking about *general, debatable opinions*.

---

If you say "I think that sushi is good," that's an *objective statement*. You're claiming it as your opinion by saying "I think" (or similarly, "I believe").

This tells us that this kind of statement should use the *indicative mood*. It is objectively your personal opinion.

---

What if you tweak your statement to say "It's great that you eat sushi"? Grammatically, this changes everything. Even though this is, of course, still your opinion, it goes from personal to *general*.

---

This kind of statement introduces an element of uncertainty and subjectivity, as it's a general statement that is now up for debate. Is it great, or is it not?

Because of this uncertainty, it lets us know we should use the subjunctive in this case.

---

Keep in mind that we're not talking about the intent behind the statements, merely about the grammar. If you say "I think..." or "I believe...", you're stating *for a fact* that this is your personal belief. It's clear that this is the truth.

---

If you say "It's important that...", you're introducing ambiguity. It could be important, or it could not. It's not clear, and that's where the subjunctive comes in.

---

Unlike many of the other situations we've talked about, it's more important to understand the structure of this kind of statement than to memorize specific phrases that tell us to use the subjunctive.

---

That being said, here are a few examples of the *types* of phrases that fit into this situation. Of course, we'll see more during the drills coming up.

- **es fantástico que** - it's fantastic that
- **es mejor que** - it's better that
- **es necesario que** - it's necessary that
- **es preferible que** - it's preferable that
- **es importante que** - it's important that
- **es ridículo que** - it's ridiculous that
- **es terrible que** - it's terrible that

---

And, naturally, negating all these results in the same situation. Whether you're saying **it's necessary that...** or **it's not necessary that...**, both will use the subjunctive.

units.description: In this pack, we'll talk about how to give commands. Get your bossy pants on, and let's go!

lessons.title: It's absolutely imperative
lessons.text:
Sometimes, you just need to tell someone do something. This is often referred to as either a **command** or an **imperative** (either is fine), and that's what we'll be learning in this unit.

---

If you have a background in Spanish (or are just very observant), you may have noticed that we've been focusing mostly on *informal* or *familiar speech*. In the most basic terms, this means using **tú** instead of **usted** when speaking to someone.

---

Most grammar textbooks will put an emphasis on learning to use **usted** from the very beginning, but it turns out that this type of *formal speech* is less common in reality, and you're better off defaulting to informal speech.

We want you to start using your Spanish quickly, rather than get confused between different forms and which you should use at any given time.

---

We're bringing this up now because it applies especially clearly to commands. There is a distinction in conjugation between formal and informal commands, but as we've been doing so far, we're going to save some of that complexity for later.

---

All right, now that we have that out of the way, how do we actually use the imperative? It's pretty simple, actually.

In English, we use the third-person present form of a verb to issue a command (**run** there, **eat** this, **give** it to me, etc.), and we do the exact same in Spanish.

---

So, you use the same verb conjugation you would use when talking about **él** or **ella** to tell someone to do something:

**Toma la foto.**
*Take the photo.*

**Come la comida.**
*Eat the food.*

**Escribe el libro.**
*Write the book.*

---

Before we talk about how to tell someone to *not* do something, let's practice telling them what *to* do!

lessons.title: That's a negative
lessons.text:
So we know how to tell someone to do something, but what about when we need to tell them *not* to do something?

In that case, we actually switch to the second-person subjunctive, using the **tú** conjugation.

---

Here are a few examples:

**No tomes la foto.**
*Don't take the photo.*

**No comas la comida.**
*Do not eat the food.*

**No escribas el libro.**
*Don't write the book.*

---

Since we already learned the subjunctive, this should be pretty straightforward. The nice thing about the imperative is that there are no new conjugations to learn, mostly just forms we've seen before being used in slightly different ways.

---

As with everything, practice makes progress, so let's get to it!

lessons.title: Irregular orders
lessons.text:
As you've probably gotten used to by now, there are a few important verbs that have irregular imperative forms. These ones should look familiar, as we've seen them many times before.

---

|  **English** |  **Infinitive**  |  **Imperative**  | 
| --------- | -------- | -------- |
| to say | decir | **di** |
| to do | hacer | **haz** |
| to go | ir | **ve** |
| to come | venir | **ven** |
| to leave | salir | **sal** |
| to have | tener | **ten** |
| to put | poner | **pon** |
| to be | ser | **sé** |

---
	
Keep in mind that this irregularity only applies in the *positive*. If you're telling someone *not* to do something, we stick with the **second-person subjunctive**, just like we use for all the regular verbs.

---

| **Infinitive**  |  **Negative Imperative**  | 
-------- | -------- |
| decir | **no digas** |
| hacer | **no hagas** |
| ir | **no vayas** |
| venir | **no vengas** |
| salir | **no salgas** |
| tener | **no tengas** |
| poner | **no pongas** |
| ser | **no seas** |

---
